questions.text: A 59-year-old woman with stage IV lung cancer comes to the physician because of progressively worsening weakness over the past 3 months. She has had a 10.5-kg (23-lb) weight loss during this period. Her BMI is 16 kg/m2. She appears thin and has bilateral temporal wasting. Which of the following is the most likely primary mechanism underlying this woman's temporal muscle atrophy?

choices.text: Cytokine-mediated decrease in basal metabolic rate

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cells digest endocytosed proteins using lysosomal hydrolases. This process protects cells from foreign proteins and is a key step in MHC class II antigen presentation. However, this is not the underlying mechanism of cancer-related skeletal muscle atrophy.

B) INCORRECT:

Cytochrome c-mediated activation of proteases (caspases) leads to cell apoptosis via the intrinsic pathway of programmed cell death. Apoptosis is associated with tissue atrophy in the setting of cancer cachexia. However, it is not the primary mechanism of cancer-related skeletal muscle atrophy.

C) INCORRECT:

Cachexia due to malignancy is associated with the release of lipid-mobilizing factors from tumor cells. These factors induce hormone-sensitive lipase to degrade triglycerides, which causes adipose tissue necrosis and atrophy but not cancer-related skeletal muscle atrophy.

D) INCORRECT:

Cytokine-mediated effects on the basal metabolic rate are a key feature of the mechanism of tumor-induced cachexia. However, cachectic agents such as TNF-α, IL-1, and IL-6 increase, rather than decrease, the basal metabolic rate. Decreasing the basal metabolic rate, or resting energy expenditure, would lead to weight gain rather than cancer-related muscle atrophy, which is seen here.

E) CORRECT:

Muscle wasting in the setting of cancer cachexia is associated with the increased release of proinflammatory cytokines such as IL-1, IL-6, and TNF-α from cancer cells. These cytokines activate NF-κB, which stimulates the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway. Ubiquitinated proteins (e.g., myosin chains in skeletal muscle cells) undergo proteasomal degradation, leading to increased muscle catabolism. TNF-α in particular is known to stimulate muscle catabolism via the alteration of hormone levels that regulate muscle growth (i.e., IGF-1, GH). Furthermore, TNF-α-mediated suppression of appetite in the hypothalamus, as well as peripheral activation of lipases, leads to the reduction of body fat. Cachexia occurs not only in the setting of cancer but also in conditions such as AIDS, COPD, heart failure, or end-stage renal disease.
questions.hint: This patient has bilateral loss of temporalis muscle mass (bilateral temporal wasting) as a result of her advanced cancer. Malignant tumor cells release agents that promote cachexia via the breakdown of structural components of skeletal muscle cells.

questions.text: A medical student is studying digestive enzymes at the brush border of the duodenum. He isolates and inactivates an enzyme in the brush border that has a high affinity for the pancreatic proenzyme trypsinogen. When the enzyme is inactivated, trypsinogen is no longer converted to its active form. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this enzyme?

choices.text: Conjugation of ubiquitin to lysine residue
Phosphorylation of an amino acid side chain
Attachment of a carbohydrate to a side chain
Cleavage of a propeptide from an N-terminus

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Attachment of ubiquitin to lysine residues is performed by ubiquitin-conjugating enzymes as part of the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway, which targets proteins for degradation. It has no role in activating trypsinogen.

B) INCORRECT:

Attachment of a phosphate residue to a hydroxy group of an amino acid side chain, or phosphorylation, is performed by protein kinases to activate or inactivate a large number of proteins. Although phosphorylation changes protein configuration and enzymatic activity, it has no role in the conversion of trypsinogen to trypsin.

C) INCORRECT:

Attachment of a carbohydrate to a side chain or a protein, a process referred to as protein glycosylation, is important in synthesizing cell membranes, as well as lysosomal and secretory glycoproteins. It has no role in the activation of trypsinogen.

D) INCORRECT:

Attachment of a carboxylic acid group, or carboxylation, to a glutamate residue alters a protein's configuration, thereby regulating its activity. It has no role in the activation of trypsinogen.

E) CORRECT:

Trypsinogen is a protease secreted from the pancreas in an inactive form (zymogen), which prevents it from damaging the surrounding tissue where it is initially released. Enteropeptidase catalyzes the cleavage of an N-terminal propeptide, converting trypsinogen to its active form of trypsin.
questions.hint: Enteropeptidase is responsible for converting the proenzyme (zymogen) trypsinogen to trypsin.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination after he was diagnosed with mantle cell lymphoma. The physician recommends a chemotherapeutic regimen containing bortezomib. Which of the following best describes the effect of this drug?

choices.text: Preventing the relaxation of DNA supercoils

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Taxanes such as docetaxel and paclitaxel impair cellular replication by stabilizing the mitotic spindle, which consists of tubulin polymers, causing mitotic arrest in metaphase. They are used to treat breast cancer, ovarian cancer, gastric cancer, and prostate cancer.

B) CORRECT:

When the ubiquitin-proteasome system is inhibited by proteasome inhibitors such as bortezomib, misfolded proteins that have undergone ubiquitination are unable to be degraded in the proteasome. This leads to cell damage and death through a variety of mechanisms, including an accumulation of apoptotic proteins such as p53.

C) INCORRECT:

Alkylating agents such as cyclophosphamide and ifosfamide impair DNA replication by crosslinking DNA at the N7 site on guanine. They are used to treat leukemias, multiple myeloma, gynecological cancers, and lung cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Topoisomerase II inhibitors such as etoposide and teniposide impair the action of topoisomerase II, which relieves supercoils in DNA during replication. This inhibition leads to decreased cell replication and increased DNA damage and degradation.

E) INCORRECT:

Tyrosine kinase inhibitors such as erlotinib and imatinib are used to treat CML and GI stromal tumors. They inhibit specific tyrosine kinases such as the Bcr-Abl fusion protein in CML.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife for a psychiatric evaluation. Over the past 12 months, his behavior has become increasingly disruptive. His wife no longer brings him along shopping because he has attempted to grope a female cashier on 2 occasions. He has begun to address the mail carrier using a racial epithet. Three years later, the patient dies. Light microscopy of sections of the frontal and temporal lobes shows intracellular inclusions of transactive response DNA binding protein (TDP-43). These proteins are bound to a regulatory molecule that usually marks them for degradation. The regulatory molecule in question is most likely which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tau proteins stabilize microtubules. Abnormal aggregates of tau proteins are seen in various neurodegenerative brain diseases, including Alzheimer disease and frontotemporal dementia, the diagnosis in this patient. However, tau proteins do not mark protein targets for degradation.

B) INCORRECT:

Kinesin and dynein are motor proteins involved in transport along microtubules (e.g., movement of synaptic vesicles along axons). Mutations in genes encoding kinesin family proteins have been found in hereditary nerve disorders such as Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease. However, kinesin does not mark other proteins for degradation.

C) INCORRECT:

Cyclins control the cell cycle and transitions between cell cycle phases. Cyclin dysfunction can lead to uncontrolled cell division that causes malignancy. Cyclins do not mark protein targets for degradation.

D) CORRECT:

Tagging with ubiquitin marks proteins for degradation by the ubiquitin-proteasome system (UPS). Dysfunction of the UPS is implicated in various neurodegenerative brain diseases, including frontotemporal dementia, as seen here, as well as Alzheimer disease, Parkinson disease, and Huntington disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Chaperone proteins assist in molecular assembly and folding of other proteins. Defects or losses of chaperone proteins can lead to protein misfolding and contribute to neurodegeneration as seen in this patient. However, chaperone proteins do not mark other proteins for degradation.

F) INCORRECT:

Clathrin is a protein that coats vesicles and assists in vesicular endocytosis and trafficking. Although dysfunction of clathrin-mediated endocytosis is hypothesized to be involved in the development of some neurodegenerative brain diseases, clathrin does not mark protein targets for degradation.
questions.hint: This man had frontotemporal dementia, which causes changes in personality and social behavior. The postmortem histopathologic findings of intracellular inclusions of TDP-43 in the frontal and temporal lobes confirms the diagnosis. Binding of the regulatory molecule in question to proteins such as TDP-43 normally results in transport of the proteins to the proteasome.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the modification of newly formed polypeptides in plated eukaryotic cells. After the polypeptides are released from the ribosome, a chemically-tagged protein attaches covalently to lysine residues on the polypeptide chain, forming a modified polypeptide. When a barrel-shaped complex is added to the cytoplasm, the modified polypeptide lyses, resulting in individual amino acids and the chemically-tagged proteins. Which of the following post-translational modifications has most likely occurred?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acylation refers to the post-translational modification of adding fatty acids to polypeptides. Addition of a hydrophobic moiety to a protein allows receptors to attach to phospholipid membranes, facilitating cell signaling and communication. However, acylation does not label the protein for degradation in the proteasome, as seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Glycosylation of proteins to form glycoproteins is a form of post-translational modification. There are many variations of glycosylation (e.g., N-linked glycosylation, O-linked glycosylation), which is an important step in proper protein folding (e.g., glycosylation of pro-α-chain hydroxylysine residues to form procollagen), cell-to-cell adhesion, and cell signaling. However, glycosylation of a protein does not label the protein for proteolysis in the proteasome.

C) INCORRECT:

Phosphorylation is a type of post-translational modification that involves the addition of phosphate ions to proteins and is involved in many cellular functions, including carbohydrate metabolism (e.g., phosphorylation of glucose to glucose-6-phosphate), enzyme regulation and cell signaling. However, phosphorylation of a protein does not label the protein for degradation in the proteasome, as is seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Carboxylation is a form of regulatory post-translational modification that involves the addition of a carboxyl group to a polypeptide. Several coagulation factors, including prothrombin, require carboxylation to achieve optimal function. However, carboxylation does not label the protein for degradation in the proteasome, as seen here.

E) CORRECT:

Ubiquitination involves the covalent addition of a small regulatory protein (ubiquitin) to a polypeptide. This post-translational modification is not limited to lysine residues, but can also occur on cysteine, serine, and threonine residues, as well as the N-terminal of proteins. While monoubiquitination is used for general trafficking of proteins within the cell, polyubiquitination tags proteins for degradation in proteasomes. Errors in ubiquitination have been implicated in the pathophysiology of Parkinson disease.
questions.hint: The barrel-shaped protein complex that degrades the modified polypeptide is a proteasome.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the structure of the amino-terminal of the Huntingtin protein using x-ray crystallography. The terminal region is determined to have an α-helix conformation. Which of the following forces is most likely responsible for maintaining this conformation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Interactions between hydrophobic (lipophilic) side chains contribute to a globular, water-soluble tertiary protein structure. In this conformation, hydrophobic components are predominantly clumped together in the interior of the molecule, and the hydrophilic components are left on the outside to freely interact with water. Hydrophobic interactions do not play a role in the formation of secondary protein structures.

B) INCORRECT:

Disulfide bonds are responsible for tertiary and quaternary protein structures (e.g., bonding of three preprocollagen α-helices to form procollagen). Disulfide bonds do not play a role in the formation of the α-helix itself.

C) INCORRECT:

Peptide bonds, which are covalent bonds between the nitrogen atom of the α-amino group of one amino acid and the carbon atom of the α-carboxyl group of the adjacent amino acid, are responsible for the primary protein structure. The primary sequence of the amino acids plays a role in determining the type of secondary structure. For instance, peptide chains rich in alanine, leucine, and glutamine organize preferentially into alpha helices. However, peptide bonds themselves do not form and maintain secondary structures.
Image Description:

To form a peptide bond, a carboxyl group (COOH) of an amino acid (AA) reacts with the amino group (NH2) of another AA. An H2O molecule is released in the process.

D) INCORRECT:

Electrostatic attraction between the ionic groups of side chains (e.g., NH3+, COO-) contributes to tertiary and quaternary protein structures. Electrostatic interactions between amino and carboxyl groups can influence secondary protein structures but only in the case of the α-amino and α-carboxyl groups of amino acids, not the amino and carboxyl groups of side chains.

E) CORRECT:

Hydrogen bonds between the hydrogen atom of the α-amino group of one amino acid and the oxygen atom of the α-carboxyl group of a neighboring amino acid are responsible for secondary protein structures, which include alpha helices and β-pleated sheets. In the case of an α-helix, the hydrogen bonds are formed between a pair of amino acids that lie 4 amino acids away from each other. In the case of a β-pleated sheet, the number of amino acids between a pair of hydrogen-bonded amino acids varies. Hydrogen bonds also contribute to the formation of the tertiary protein structure but, in this case, the hydrogen bonds are typically formed between side chains. Similar hydrogen bonds with oxygen and nitrogen atoms of nitrogenous bases are responsible for the double helical structure of DNA.
questions.hint: An α-helix is a secondary protein structure.

questions.text: A 1-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination after the results of newborn screening showed an increased serum concentration of phenylalanine. Genetic analysis confirms a diagnosis of phenylketonuria. The physician counsels the patient's family on the recommended dietary restrictions, including avoidance of artificial sweeteners that contain aspartame. Aspartame is a molecule composed of aspartate and phenylalanine and its digestion can lead to hyperphenylalaninemia in patients with phenylketonuria. Which of the following enzymes is primarily responsible for the breakdown of aspartame?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pepsin, a gastric endopeptidase, cleaves peptide bonds within protein molecules and targets specific peptide bonds between hydrophobic and aromatic amino acids (e.g., phenylalanine-tryptophan). Pepsin does not target peptide bonds involving hydrophilic amino acids such as aspartate. Moreover, aspartame has two terminal amino acids and can only be broken down by an enzyme with exopeptidase activity.

B) CORRECT:

Dipeptidase is a brush border enzyme in the human duodenum, jejunum, and ileum. It is a type of exopeptidase that hydrolyzes dipeptides such as aspartame.
Image Description:

In the stomach, gastric acid denatures dietary proteins, and pepsin cleaves the denatured proteins into peptides of various lengths.

In the duodenum, peptides are cleaved by exopeptidases (proteases that split peptide bonds at terminal ends, e.g. Carboxypeptidase A and B) and endopeptidases (proteases that split peptide bonds within the polypeptide chain, e.g. Trypsin, Chymotrypsin, Elastase).

Oligopeptides are broken down to di-/tripeptides by oligopeptidases at the enterocyte brush border. Some di-/tripeptides are absorbed into the enterocyte via a proton symporter (PepT1), and some remain in the intestinal lumen are broken down to amino acids in the intestinal lumen. Oligopeptides are also broken down to amino acids by aminopeptidases at the enterocyte brush border.

Within the enterocyte, dipeptides/tripeptides that were absorbed by the enterocyte are broken down to single amino acids by dipeptidases/tripeptidases.

Single amino acids within the intestinal lumen are absorbed by the enterocyte via Na+-coupled carrier proteins for specific amino acid groups (e.g. basic, neutral, acidic).

Single amino acids are transported out of the enterocyte (via basolateral transporters) into the bloodstream and travel to the liver via the portal vein.

C) INCORRECT:

Chymotrypsin, a pancreatic endopeptidase, cleaves peptide bonds within protein molecules and targets specific peptide bonds between hydrophobic and aromatic amino acids (e.g., phenylalanine-tryptophan). Chymotrypsin does not target peptide bonds involving hydrophilic amino acids such as aspartate. Moreover, aspartame has two terminal amino acids and can only be broken down by an enzyme with exopeptidase activity.

D) INCORRECT:

Trypsin, a pancreatic endopeptidase, cleaves peptide bonds within protein molecules and targets specific peptide bonds that contain the positively charged amino acids arginine or lysine. Trypsin does not target peptide bonds involving the hydrophobic amino acid phenylalanine or the negatively charged aspartate. Moreover, aspartame has two terminal amino acids and can only be broken down by an enzyme with exopeptidase activity.

E) INCORRECT:

Carboxypeptidase A, a pancreatic exopeptidase, cleaves peptide bonds at the carboxyterminal end and preferentially targets peptide bonds with aromatic amino acids such as phenylalanine. Aspartame, a dipeptide, has a carboxyterminal phenylalanine residue. However, in dipeptides the rate of peptide bond hydrolysis by carboxypeptidase A is very slow; a different type of exopeptidase is primarily responsible for their breakdown.
questions.hint: Aspartame is primarily cleaved by a brush border enzyme on the villi of the mucosa in the small intestine.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man with newly diagnosed HIV-1 infection is started on a regimen that includes a protease inhibitor. This drug binds tightly in the active site of HIV protease, preventing it from cleaving the precursor HIV Gag-Pol polyprotein chain into its constituent enzymes and structural proteins. Normally, HIV protease hydrolyzes a specific covalent functional group between the terminal carboxyl group of one amino acid and the terminal nitrogen group of the next amino acid in the chain. Which of the following terms best describes the chemical bond targeted by HIV protease?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Disulfide bridges are formed by sulfur–sulfur connections between cysteine residues of polypeptide chains and help stabilize the three-dimensional conformation of proteins (tertiary or quaternary structures of proteins). The described bond is not a disulfide bridge.

B) INCORRECT:

Ester bonds involve a carbon-oxygen linkage typically found in fats (e.g., triglycerides) and certain metabolic intermediates. While ester linkages may appear in phospholipids of viral membranes, they are not the principal link between amino acids in a polypeptide chain.

C) CORRECT:

Amide bonds (–CO–NH–) result from a condensation reaction between the carboxyl group (COOH) of one amino acid and the amino group (NH2) of another, releasing water. This bond is responsible for the primary structure of proteins. Such a covalent connection is susceptible to hydrolysis by proteases. HIV protease cleaves a nonfunctional precursor protein into structural components (Gag) and enzymes essential for viral replication (Pol). Protease inhibitors block the cleavage of the large viral protein chain at precise sites, leading to defective viral replication and assembly.

Key learning point: An amide bond links the terminal carboxyl group of one amino acid with the terminal amino group of another.
Image Description:

To form a peptide bond, a carboxyl group (COOH) of an amino acid (AA) reacts with the amino group (NH2) of another AA. An H2O molecule is released in the process.

D) INCORRECT:

Phosphodiester linkages form the backbone of nucleic acids, joining adjacent nucleotides in DNA and RNA. Although HIV’s replication requires processing of its genetic material for replication, protease inhibitors do not directly target the phosphodiester backbone of viral RNA or DNA. Instead, it prevents the cutting of a completely different linkage essential for polypeptide processing.

E) INCORRECT:

A glycosidic bond is the covalent connection between two monosaccharides in carbohydrates, such as the bond between glucose units in cellulose or starch. While carbohydrates do form essential components of glycoproteins on viral surfaces, a β-1,4 glycosidic linkage is not the bond that would be targeted in viral polyproteins.
